descriptiveNote.p: There are two other possible dates of birth: 4 September 1862 and 29 September 1862, and the date of death is unknown.

biogHist.p: Donald MacDonald was the son of Alexander MacDonald (1832–1872), farmer (or rather tenant) in Snaoiseabhal, South Uist, and his wife Catherine MacDonald née MacDonald (1831–75). The official record states that he was born on 4 September 1862, while the church register from Ardkenneth records his birthday as 28 August; he was baptised on 14 September. It is noteworthy that his grandfather Duncan told Carmichael that Donald was born on Latha Fhéill Mìcheil, 29 September! [CW107/43].

Donald’s father Alexander, Alasdair Ruadh, had the patronymic Alasdair ’ic Dhomhnaill ’ic Dhomhnaill ’ic Iain ’ic Dhomhnaill ’ic Iain ’ic Iain ’ic Raghnaill Bhòrnais. This Ranald will have been the first of the Bornish line, living in the later part of the sixteenth century [A. & A. MacDonald, The Clan Donald (3 vols, Inverness, 1896–1904), 258–9]: the family were known as Sliochd Iain ’ic Raghnaill after his son. Through his paternal grandmother Ann MacEachen Donald was related twice to Marshal Étienne Jacques Joseph Alexandre MacDonald (1765–1840), the Duke of Tarentum: her father, Alexander MacEachen (d. 1835), the last tacksman of his line of Tobha Beag, was the son of John of Tobha Beag, the brother of the Marshal’s father Neil MacEachen; he was also supposedly the grandson of a brother of Alexander’s grandmother through his paternal Bornish line, though a generation may have been omitted here.

Donald’s mother Catherine was the daughter of the seanchaidh Duncan MacDonald (c. 1787–1873), Donnchadh an Tàilleir. The couple were married on 25 February 1862. There were three other daughters of the marriage: Mary (1865–1954), Ann (b. 1867), and Margaret (b. 1869). Mary, Màiri nighean Alasdair Ruaidh, was known for her repertoire of stories and songs, especially waulking songs [see K. C. Craig (ed.), Òrain Màiri nighean Alasdair (Glasgow, 1949)].

Alexander Carmichael recorded from Donald MacDonald while he was in the home of his grandfather Duncan. It is unclear whether he was living with him at the time, though this is certainly the case by the 1871 census. Whatever was the case, Carmichael did not record Donald on the first day he interviewed his grandfather, 6 April 1869. The following day, however, the six year old Donald was introduced to Carmichael by his grandfather: ‘He can rep[ea]t correctly all this Taladh Iain Mhuideartaich [del: Tormaid] Mac mhic ic Ailein – Bhean leasaich an stop – Sir Alastar og thig on chaol, Laoi[dh] na Buileartaich, Laoi[dh] Fhraoich[,] Dun Mhic Iain ic Iain &c &c’ [CW107/43].

Donald began by singing a lengthy version of Tàladh Iain Mhùideartaich [CW107/43], then, probably, the quern song ‘Beil a Chailleach a’ Bhrà’ [CW107/44]. Carmichael subsequently wrote down from him the text of the Fenian ballad Laoidh a’ Mhuileartaich [CW107/46], and a lament ‘do Thormaid Mac Mhic ic Ailein’ [CW107/48, for a Norman son of MacDonald of Clan Ranald who had died of yellow fever while studying in France – possibly the mysterious son of Ranald (1692–1766) recorded in Clan Donald iii as having studied law in Glasgow, although ‘[n]othing further is known of him’ [A. & A. MacDonald, The Clan Donald (3 vols, Inverness, 1896–1904), 235]. All of these were learnt from his grandfather. A further conversation took place about Easter Eggs (Easter having taken place the week before) [CW107/50], before the boy recited the Fenian ballad Laoidh Fhraoich [CW107/51], then finished off with the hymn Laoidh Chrìosd [CW107/52].
Twenty years later Carmichael was to reminisce about his meeting with ‘this wonderful child of song modesty and memory’ [CW172]:

‘The only difficulty experienced with this boy was childlike, his disposition to gambol about with his companions. There were a kitten, a pup, and a lamb in the house and every now and then these three and the boy rose and had a frolic on the floor together. The boy's grandfather Donl mac an taillear, Donald son [of] the tailor – a nice old man sat in a corner enveloped in friendly peat smoke and now and again scolded the boy in a friendly way for not attending to the gentleman. At last fairly tired and done up these four playful delightful and frolicsome creatures lay down on the floor beside the friendly fire of peat and fell fast asleep. A shaggy little six-horned sheep an equally shagg[y] symmetrical black calf and a sturdy ragged little foal all by times and [supra: sometimes] together looked in and sniffed the nestling group beside the fire.’ [CW172]

‘One of the most delightful [reciters] was a boy Donald Macdonald son of a small crofter at Snaoisvall South Uist. He was then nearly six years of age, bare footed bare headed with a scant kilt out of which he had [del: over] grown a year or two [supra: before]. … The boys grandfather was sitting upon a bench in a dark corner and I was sitting upon the bench near him. The boy was sitting upon the base clay floor before the bright peat fire but more often rolling upon the floor with one arm round the neck a half grown lamb and another arm bound the neck of a half grown collie dog. The three lay stretched side by side the boy in the middleand had a little sleep as was their wont after tiring themselves out in play. Every now and then a half grown pig would come and look in from turning the peat moss outside. In a spirit of pure mischief the pig would give a nip at the [del: ear] [supra: nose] of the dog the toe of the [del: dog] [supra: boy] or at the ear of the lamb. The aggrieved subject gave a squeel [sic] and the pig disappeared into space the three whose slumbering it had disturbed following in hot haste the lamb contenting itself with looking at its two companions castigating the offender. At other times the pig would come in and lie down and sleep beside the three sleeping and share their potatoes and was at home mostly then.’ [CW124 fos.50–2]

The writer, meanwhile, ‘tired and fatigued … drew his cloak over him and stretching himself on the wooden bench Gaelic, Seise, on which he sat, fell fast asleep and slept soundly till the cold awoke him in the grey dawn of the morning’ [CW172 fo.3]. This reminiscence is contradicted by the contemporary evidence of the field notebook, which suggests that, after having recorded from the MacDonalds, Carmichael walked about a mile or so to his friend Peggy Robertson, Tobha Mòr, where he wrote down the texts of three fairy songs, before travelling north again to the grieve Alexander MacDonald’s house at Driomor where he spent the night.

Although Alexander Carmichael returned to Duncan MacDonald’s house in Snaoiseabhal for a second time on 28 March 1871 [CW119/19-21], he made no more recording from his grandson Donald. After his grandparents’ deaths in the 1870s, Donald continued to live in the household with his uncle Donald and aunt Catherine: he appears as a labourer there in the 1881 census. It is known that in October 1881 he married Ann MacEachan at Bornish. It is possible that he is the 28-year old Donald MacDonald recorded in the 1891 census as an agricultural labourer, a monoglot Gaelic speaker, on the glebe of the parish minister the Rev. Roderick MacDonald at Dreumasdail. Donald MacDonald’s later life is yet to be traced.
